children.name: wrong in what you say or think
wrong
children.definition: if you are wrong, you think or say sth that is not correct:

children.name: completely/totally/quite wrong
examples: I may be completely wrong.

children.name: hopelessly wrong
examples: In most cases judges are right, but in a few they are hopelessly wrong.

children.name: be proved wrong
children.definition: be shown to be wrong
examples: People do not like to be proved wrong.

children.name: be wrong (about sb/sth)
examples: No, you’re wrong. Brett wouldn’t do a thing like that.
I was wrong about the new guy – he’s not Belgian, he’s French.
You were wrong about that train - it left at 10.30.
That’s where you’re wrong! We never slept together.

children.name: be wrong in thinking/believing etc something
examples: You’d be wrong in thinking we don’t encourage disabled students to come to the college.

children.name: mistaken
children.definition: to have an incorrect opinion or belief about sth - use this as a polite way of saying sb is wrong:

children.name: be mistaken
examples: I thought it was an accident, but I was mistaken.

children.name: be mistaken about
examples: Anna realised she had been mistaken about Dennis.

children.name: you must be mistaken
examples: I think you must be mistaken. He could not have obtained a key to your room.

children.name: be misinformed
children.definition: to be wrong because you have been given information that is incorrect or untrue:
examples: ▪ I think you must have been misinformed -- we don’t teach any courses in business studies here.

children.name: be misinformed about
examples: ▪ The documents clearly show that the public was misled and misinformed about the crisis.

children.name: on the wrong track
children.definition: be /tack  to have the wrong idea about a situation, so that you are unlikely to get the result you want or the right answer to a problem:
examples: ▪ I feel that this advertising campaign is on completely the wrong tack.

children.name: get somebody off on the wrong tack/track
examples: ▪ He admitted that he had gotten us off on the wrong tack, and that we’d need to start again.

children.name: kid/delude yourself
children.definition: to wrongly and stupidly let yourself believe something that you want to believe, but which is not true:
examples: ▪ He’s kidding himself if he thinks he’s going to be a great film director.
▪ Don’t delude yourself. They have no intention of offering you a job.

children.name: in the wrong order, position, etc
wrong
children.definition: ▪ Someone had moved the road sign so it was pointing in the  direction.
examples: ▪ You’re heading in the wrong direction for the city centre.
▪ The files had been put back in the wrong order.

children.name: the wrong way aroundbe / the wrong way roundBritish
examples: a)to be in the wrong order :
These two paragraphs are the wrong way round.
Tom often writes ‘b’ and ‘d’ the wrong way round.
That hat looks a bit strange -- have you got it on the wrong way around?
b)if something is the wrong way round, the back is where the front should be :
You’ve got your T-shirt on the wrong way around.
The torch won’t work if you put the batteries in the wrong way round.

children.name: the wrong way up
children.definition: if sth is the wrong way up, the top is where the bottom should beSYN upside down:
examples: The painting was hung the wrong way up.

children.name: a wrong statement, answer, calculation, etc
wrong
children.definition: not correct:
examples: For every answer that is wrong, you lose five points.
I think that clock must be wrong showing the wrong time.
Your calculations must be wrong.

children.name: wrong (telephone) number/address/name etc
examples: I tried to phone him, but it was the wrong number.

children.name: This must be the wrong address -- no one of that name lives here
examples: get sth wrongThey’ve got their sums wrong.
I think I got question 3 wrong .

children.name: incorrect
children.definition: facts, figures, answers etc that areincorrect are wrong because they are not the same as the correct ones.Incorrectis more formal thanwrong:
examples: ▪ The information about current prices was incorrect.

children.name: ▪ incorrect spelling
examples: ▪ They discovered later that the doctor had made an incorrect diagnosis.

children.name: it is incorrect to do/say sth
examples: ▪ It’s simply incorrect to say that tobacco advertising does not influence young people.

children.name: inaccurate
children.definition: information, numbers etc that areinaccurate are not exactly right or contain some mistakes:
examples: A lot of what has been written about him is inaccurate.

children.name: inaccurate information/data etc
examples: He was fined $300,000 for making inaccurate statements to Congress.
The old maps were usually inaccurate or incomplete.
TV ratings figures are often inaccurate.
He admitted he had given the committee ‘inaccurate, incomplete and unreliable information’.

children.name: totally/wildly inaccuratevery inaccurate
examples: Figures quoted in the article are wildly inaccurate.

children.name: out
children.definition: be UK /be offUS  if a measurement, result, figure etc is out, it is wrong because the numbers have not been calculated correctly: sai
examples: ▪ These sales figures must be out. We certainly haven’t made that much money this year.

children.name: be out by $10/50 centimetres etc
examples: ▪ My last bank statement was off by $60.

children.name: off the mark
children.definition: be way   if someone’s guess, opinion etcis way off the mark,their idea about a situation is completely wrong:
examples: ▪ No, you’re way off the mark -- he was born in 1736.

children.name: a wrong idea, belief, action, etc
wrong
children.definition: not based on true facts
examples: People used to believe that the world was flat, but we now know this is wrong.
Alice felt she had made the wrong decision.

children.name: get the wrong impression
examples: I wouldn’t like you to get the wrong impression -- I do enjoy the course, but I just find it veryhard work.

children.name: it is wrong to do sth
examples: It is wrong to assume that technological advance brings a higher quality of life.

children.name: mistaken
children.definition: mistaken idea/belief/impression etcan idea, belief etc that people believe is right but is in fact wrong - use this as a polite way of saying someone is wrong:
examples: Many people have the mistaken idea that AIDS cannot spread through heterosexual sex.

children.name: under the mistaken belief/impression etc
examples: Pauline was under the mistaken impression that I didn’t like her.

children.name: false
children.definition: based on wrong ideas or incorrect information:
examples: He gave false and misleading statements to the court.
My mother avoided visiting Bali on the quite false assumption that the place is full of tourists.
false assumptionsabout people of other cultures
a false sense of security(= a feeling of being safe when you are not really safe )
give a false impression/belief
The title gives a false impression of what the book is actually about.
I don’t want to give you anyfalse hopes.
The statement gives us afalse impressionthat we understand something when we do not.

children.name: erroneous
children.definition: based on incorrect or incomplete information:
examples: ▪ There were erroneous reports that the company had issued false statements.
erroneously[adverb]
▪ It is sometimes erroneously believed that cutting interest rates will cure all our economic problems.

children.name: erroneous assumption/view/belief etc
examples: ▪ Ricci’s book tries to correct this erroneous view of ancient China.

children.name: misplaced
children.definition: misplaced trust/loyalty/admiration/concern etctrust, loyalty etc that is wrong because there is no good reason for feeling it: “đặt để không đúng chỗ”
examples: Richards said, with misplaced confidence, that the ship was ‘unsinkable’.
I suppose her chief fault was misplaced trust, rather than any real crime.

children.name: (do sth out of) a sense of misplaced loyalty/admiration etc
examples: Despite her doubts, she supported the new legislation out of a misplaced sense of loyalty to theleadership.

children.name: misguided
children.definition: a misguided decision, belief, action etc is wrong because it is based on bad judgement or understanding: sai lầm, lầm lạc
examples: ▪ These decision now seem misguided, if not downright wrong.

children.name: misguided efforts/attempt/action etc
examples: ▪ It was another of his misguided attempts to save money.

children.name: (do sth in the) misguided belief/hope
examples: ▪ The taxes were introduced in the misguided belief that they would reduce foreign competition.

children.name: wrongheaded
children.definition: wrong and a little stupid, because of being based on a lack of understanding:
examples: The young man’s speech was full of wrongheaded ideas about ‘the evils of capitalism’.

children.name: wrong
children.definition: not in the correct wayOPP right:
examples: You’ve spelt my name wrong.
What? Have Idoneitwrong?
I asked him to sort those files, but he’sdone it all wrong(= in completely the wrong way ).
You’ve spelled my name wrong -- there should be an ‘e’ at the end.

children.name: incorrectly
children.definition: If a player answers , the question is given to the other team.
examples: Sorry, you answered incorrectly.

children.name: wrongly
children.definition: I think you’ve added it up .

children.name: upside down
children.definition: if something isupside down,the top of it is at the bottom and the bottom of it is at the top:
examples: ▪ You’re holding the picture upside down.
▪ The monkey was hanging upside down from a tree.

children.name: turn something upside down
examples: ▪ Turn the cups upside down and leave them to dry.

children.name: inside out
children.definition: if something, especially a piece of clothing, isinside out, the inside of it is on the outside and the outside of it is on the inside:
examples: ▪ I put my socks on inside out by mistake.
▪ The wind was so strong, it blew her umbrella inside out.

children.name: turn something inside out
examples: ▪ I turned the jeans inside out to repair the hem.

children.name: misleading
children.definition: a statement or piece of information that ismisleadingmakes people believe something that is not true, especially because it does not give all the facts:

children.name: sai sự thật
examples: ▪ The article was deliberately misleading, and the newspaper has apologized.

children.name: ▪ misleading statistics
examples: ▪ The Advertising Review Board says the adverts are deliberately misleading.

children.name: give a misleading impression/statement etc
examples: ▪ Agents often gave a false or misleading description of the houses they were selling.

children.name: back to frontBritish alsobackwardsBritish /backward American
children.definition: if something, especially a piece of clothing, isback to front,the back of it is where the front should be:
examples: ▪ You’ve got your sweater on back to front.
▪ Dan appeared in jeans, wearing his cap backward as usual.
